text: In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Verily, praise be to Allah, we praise Him, seek His help, and ask for His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our souls and the bad consequences of our deeds. Whomever Allah guides, no one can lead him astray, and whomever He leads astray, no one can guide him. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, with no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger. May Allah send blessings and abundant peace upon him. To proceed: We are pleased to place before the readers and students of knowledge the book "Kitab Al-Qadar" by the Imam, the Hafiz, the ascetic Abdullah bin Wahb Al-Qurashi Al-Masri, who died in the year (197 AH), may Allah Almighty have mercy on him. In this book, the author, may Allah have mercy on him, followed the method of the predecessors (Salaf) in their compilations at that time. He listed the Prophetic Hadiths and Salafi traditions affirming Divine Decree and Destiny without commentary or chapter headings. Yes, his arrangement of the hadiths and traditions might suggest they are ordered according to a general thematic sequence, but he did not assign chapter headings at all. Furthermore, the copyist Abu Bakr; Muhammad bin Ismail - who is the narrator of the book - added to the original book hadiths from his sheikhs, which are essentially extractions and corroborations for the book's hadiths (1).
foot_note: 1. I distinguished these additions by placing the letter (z) after the hadith number, noting that I maintained the numbering of Sheikh Al-Uthaym.

text: It should be noted that this book was printed with the verification of Dr. Abdul Aziz Abdul Rahman Muhammad Al-Uthaym, may Allah have mercy on him, in the year (1406) in Makkah Al-Mukarramah. What prompted me to re-verify and publish it, despite the prior work of Sheikh Al-Uthaym, may Allah have mercy on him, are several matters, including: 1 - The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, intervened directly in the text of the book; by modification, substitution, addition, and deletion; sometimes indicating this action, and neglecting it at other times. It is no secret that this approach is dangerous with undesirable consequences. I will give some examples and models of his action: On page (152) of his printed version: The copyist commented on the hadith of Jarir bin Hazim, from Al-A'mash, from Zaid bin Wahb, from Ibn Masoud, saying: "This is a strange chain from Jarir bin Hazim, from Al-A'mash." Sheikh Al-Uthaym, may Allah have mercy on him, modified it to: "This is a chain [that is not strange] from Jarir bin Hazim, from Al-A'mash." His basis: The copyist's words - in his view - contradict the corroborations he cited for the hadith! It is no secret that the copyist meant relative strangeness, not absolute. Whatever the case may be; his statement should not be modified. On page (157): The copyist said: "And the rest of the paths of this hadith from

So the Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, replaced it with his saying: "And the rest of the paths of the hadith of Zaid bin Wahb come in the hadith of [Salamah bin Kuhayl]" because his phrase is more correct than the copyist's phrase, as he said. On page (137): Hadith of Ibn Umar: "When Allah Almighty wants to create the soul, the angel of the wombs says with it...". Thus it appeared "with it" in the three manuscripts of "Kitab Al-Qadar" by Ibn Wahb. And in the manuscript originals of "Shifa Al-Alil" by Ibn Al-Qayyim - where he transmitted this hadith with its chain and text - and in "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" by Al-Mizzi where he narrated the hadith with its chain via "Kitab Al-Qadar" by Ibn Wahb. And Al-Mizzi noted that it occurred like this in the narration "with it". So the Sheikh deleted it and put in its place "turning away" and did not indicate in the slightest this action (1). As for the additions, they are numerous, appended from other narrations of the hadith to complete the benefit. There is no doubt that Ibn Wahb was not concerned with them. What indicates that they did not appear in the original book: Those who quoted from "Kitab Al-Qadar" in the past like Ibn Al-Qayyim and others transmitted its hadiths and narrated them without those additions. text: Al-Nasa'i said: Trustworthy, I do not know him to have narrated a rejected hadith from trustworthy narrators. Al-Khalili said: Trustworthy, agreed upon. It was held against him that he was lenient in taking [hadith]. Al-Nasa'i said: He was lenient in taking; and there is no harm in him. Al-Saji said: Truthful, trustworthy, and was one of the worshippers, and was lenient in hearing; because the madhhab of the people of his country is that Ijaza (license) is permissible for them, and he says in it: So-and-so told me. Ibn Adi included him in "Al-Kamil" for this reason. Al-Dhahabi said: Ibn Adi was stubborn in including him in "Al-Kamil". From Yahya bin Ma'in: That he heard Ibn Wahb saying to Sufyan bin Uyaynah: O Abu Muhammad, the hadiths - meaning: what so-and-so presented to you yesterday - license them for me. He said: Yes. Al-Dhahabi commented: This is the madhhab of the group, and if there is blame on Abdullah for it, then Ibn Uyaynah is his partner in it. I say: And this mentioned leniency does not affect his hadith at all; because he did not include them in his compilations and narrations. Imam Ahmad said: It reached me that he did not include anything of those in his compilation. He also said: Abdullah bin Wahb is sound in hadith, he separates hearing from presentation, and hadith from hadith, how sound and firm his hadith is! It was said to him: Was he not bad in taking?

text: He said: He might be bad in taking, but if you look at his hadith, what he narrated from his sheikhs you find it sound. It was also held against him: That in his narration from Ibn Jurayj there are solitary reports and errors. Yahya bin Ma'in said: He is not that [strong] regarding Ibn Jurayj, he used to consider him young. Ahmad said: In the hadith of Ibn Wahb from Ibn Jurayj there is something. Abu Awanah said: He [i.e., Ahmad bin Hanbal] spoke the truth; because he brings things from him that others do not bring. Whatever is said; the rejected reports and errors in the vast amount he narrated are rare and few, indeed the authors of the two Sahihs extracted his narration from Ibn Jurayj. Ibn Adi said: And Abdullah bin Wahb is among the majestic people, and their trustworthy ones, and the hadith of Hejaz and Egypt, and what is related to those lands, revolves around the narration of Ibn Wahb, and he collected for them their musnad (connected) and maqtu' (disconnected)... And I do not know of a rejected hadith for him if a trustworthy person narrates from him. Al-Dhahabi said: He included many disconnected and perplexing reports in his compilations, and narrated much from Ibn Sam'an and his ilk, and some Imams criticized Ibn Wahb in his taking of hadith, and that he was lenient in taking, and whether he was lenient and saw that permissible, or strict, whoever narrates a hundred thousand hadiths, and rejected reports are rare in the vastness of what he narrated, then he has reached the utmost in precision. Yunus bin Abd al-A'la said: The judiciary was offered to Ibn Wahb, so he feigned madness, and stayed in his house. It was said: That when he was asked to take over the judiciary of Egypt; he hid with Harmalah bin Yahya for a year and months.

text: Description of the Manuscripts Relied Upon in the Verification 1 - Escorial Copy (The Original): It is an old precious copy, located within a collection comprising a number of books on Hadith and Rijal, preserved in the Escorial Monastery in Spain, and a paper copy of it is in the library of the Holy Mosque in Mecca. Number of folios: (6) plates, equivalent to (11) pages. The number of lines per page ranges between 27 - 28 lines. Its script is poor, and mostly unpointed. See: "Al-Ilal" by Al-Daraqutni (2/ 222), "Al-Ahadith Allati Khulifa Fiha Malik" by him also p. (156), "Tahdhib Al-Kamal" (27/ 556), "Tafsir Ibn Kathir" (Al-A'raf: 172). While Malik's disconnected narration was preferred by: Ibn Abd al-Barr, and Ibn Al-Qayyim. "Shifa Al-Alil" p. (69). Al-Tirmidhi said: This is a Hasan (good) hadith, and Muslim bin Yasar did not hear from Omar. Ibn Abd al-Barr said: This hadith - even if its chain has defects - its meaning from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, has been narrated from many aspects.

He said: "This is a book from the Lord of the Worlds, in it are the names of the people of Paradise, and the names of their fathers and tribes, and it was summed up* to the last of them, so none will be added to them, nor decreased from them ever, and this is the book of the people of the Fire with their names, and the names of their fathers and tribes, and it was summed up to the last of them, so none will be added to them nor decreased from them ever." The companions (1) of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Then what is the point of deeds; if the matter has been finished? The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Be steadfast and come close, for the person of Paradise will be sealed (2) for him with the work of the people of Paradise, even if he did whatever work, and the person of the Fire will be sealed for the Fire (3), even if he did whatever work, your Lord Mighty and Majestic has finished with the Book (4)".

(34) (z) - My father, may Allah have mercy on him, told us (2), said: Ali bin Harb Al-Ta'i told us, said: Sufyan bin Uyaynah told us, so he mentioned with his chain from Hudhayfah bin Asid, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) similar to it (3). And Ubaidullah (4) bin Abi Talha Al-Makki narrated it from Abu Al-Tufayl.
foot_note:
1. Al-Humaidi narrated it (826), and from his path Al-Tabarani in 'Al-Kabir' # (3039). Ahmad narrated it (4/6). Muslim narrated it # (2644) Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Numayr and Zuhair bin Harb told us. Abu Awanah narrated it in his 'Mustakhraj' [See 'Ithaf Al-Maharah' 4/214], Al-Tahawi in 'Bayan Mushkil Ahadith Rasul Allah SAWS' # (2663), and Al-Lalaka'i # (1045) from Yunus bin Abd al-A'la. Abu Awanah also narrated it from Ibrahim bin Yasar. Ibn Abi Asim narrated it in 'Al-Sunnah' # (186) Ibn Kasib told us. All of them (Al-Humaidi, Ahmad bin Hanbal, Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Numayr, Zuhair bin Harb, Yunus bin Abd al-A'la, Ibrahim bin Yasar, and Ibn Kasib) from Sufyan bin Uyaynah with it. 
2. In (Z) and (H): Told us. 
3. Ibn Batta narrated it in 'Al-Ibanah' # (1403) from Ali bin Harb Al-Ta'i with it. 
4. Thus in the three manuscripts 'Ubaidullah', and in the manuscript of 'Usul Al-Sunnah' by Ibn Abi Zamanin similarly; where he narrated it from the path of Ibn Wahb. And it appeared in 'Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil' by Ibn Abi Hatim (5/ # 1895): 'Ubaid' without the addition, as well as in 'Al-Tahdhib' and its branches.

text: (35) - Abu Bakr, Abdullah bin Suleiman bin Al-Ash'ath told us (1), said: Ahmad bin Sa'id Al-Hamdani told us, said: Abdullah bin Wahb informed us, said: Ibn Lahi'ah informed me, from Yazid bin Abi Habib, from Ubaidullah (2) bin Abi Talha Al-Makki, that Abu Al-Tufayl Al-Bakri informed him, that he heard Ibn Masoud say: Indeed, the wretched one is he who was wretched in his mother's womb, and the happy one is he who takes heed from others. So I said: How can one be wretched who has not acted? So I met Hudhayfah bin Asid Al-Ghifari, and informed him of what Ibn Masoud said, so he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: «Indeed, when Allah wants to create the servant; the Angel says: O Lord, male or female? So the Lord says what He wills, and the angel writes. Then the angel says: O Lord, wretched or happy? So the Lord says what He wills, and the angel writes. Then he says: O our Lord, what will he encounter? So the Lord says what He wills, and the angel writes. Then the angel says: O our Lord, what is his provision? So the Lord Mighty and Majestic says what He wills, and the angel writes. Then the angel says: O our Lord, what is his lifespan? So the Lord says what He wills, and the angel writes» (3).
foot_note:
1. In (Z) and (H): Told us. 
2. See footnote (4) previous page. 
3. Ibn Abi Zamanin narrated it in 'Usul Al-Sunnah' # (122) from the path of Yunus bin Abd al-A'la, from Ibn Wahb with it. Al-Tabarani narrated it in 'Al-Kabir' # (3043) from Al-Nadr bin Abd al-Jabbar, from Ibn Lahi'ah with it. Abu Dawud narrated it in 'Al-Qadar' [See 'Tahdhib Al-Kamal' (19/218)] from Yazid bin Abi Habib with it. And Ubaid bin Abi Talha Al-Makki: Ibn Abi Hatim mentioned him in 'Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil' (5/ # 1895), and remained silent about him. Ibn Hajar said in 'Al-Taqrib': Acceptable. And Ibn Lahi'ah, discussion on him preceded at Hadith # (27).

text: (36) - Abdullah bin Suleiman told us, said: Al-Hamdani told us, said: Ibn Wahb informed us, said: Abdullah bin Lahi'ah informed me, from Bakr bin Sawadah Al-Judhami, from Abu Tamim Al-Jayshani, from Abu Dharr, that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: «When it enters - meaning: the drop - the womb for forty nights; the Angel of the Soul comes, then ascends to the Lord, and says: O Lord, is Your servant male or female? So Allah decrees what He is decreeing (1). Wretched or happy? So He writes what is to be» and he mentioned the rest of the hadith (2).
foot_note:
1. Thus in the three manuscripts, and in the manuscript originals of 'Shifa Al-Alil'. In the rest of the narrations of the hadith it occurred after 'decreeing': 'Then he says: O Lord'. And Allah knows best. 
2. Ibn Al-Qayyim quoted it in 'Shifa Al-Alil' p. (101) from 'Kitab Al-Qadar' by Ibn Wahb with its chain and text identical. Al-Darimi narrated it in 'Al-Radd 'ala Al-Jahmiyyah' # (94) from Amr bin Khalid Al-Harrani, from Ibn Lahi'ah with it Marfu' (elevated) as well. Ibn Batta narrated it in 'Al-Ibanah' # (1417) from Al-Mattuthi, said: Abu Dawud told us, said: Ahmad bin Sa'id Al-Hamdani told us, said: Ibn Wahb informed us, from Ibn Lahi'ah with it. Mawquf (stopped) at Abu Dharr. Thus this narration appeared in the printed version of 'Al-Ibanah': stopped at Abu Dharr; contrary to the narration we have which is elevated. Allah knows best. Ibn Wahb was followed up in this stopped narration: Al-Firyabi narrated it # (123) from Qutaibah bin Sa'id. Ibn Jarir Al-Tabari narrated it in his 'Tafsir' # (34187) [Al-Taghabun: 2] from Hasan bin Musa Al-Ashyab. Both of them: (Qutaibah bin Sa'id, and Al-Hasan bin Musa Al-Ashyab) from Ibn Lahi'ah with it Mawquf. This inconsistency is due to the weakness of Ibn Lahi'ah himself. And Allah knows best. The Scholar Abd al-Rahman bin Yahya Al-Mu'allimi, may Allah have mercy on him, said: 'In its chain is Ibn Lahi'ah, and the denounced part of it is: So he ascends with it to the Compeller. And its meaning without it is established in the two Sahihs and others from the hadith of Ibn Masoud'. His comment on 'Al-Fawa'id Al-Majmu'ah' p. (451), and see Hadith # (45) of this book.

text: (37) - Abdullah bin Suleiman told us, Ahmad bin Sa'id Al-Hamdani told us, said: Abdullah bin Wahb informed us, said: Jarir bin Hazim informed me, from Sulayman bin Mihran, from Zaid bin Wahb, from Abdullah bin Masoud, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «The drop remains in the womb for forty nights as a drop, and forty nights as a clot, and forty nights as a morsel. Then an angel is sent to it, and he is commanded with four words: with his provision, his lifespan, his trace, and wretched or happy. By the One in Whose Hand is the soul of Ibn Masoud, a man performs the deeds of the people of Paradise; until there is nothing between him and it except an arm's length; then the Book overtakes him; so he performs the deeds of the people of the Fire and enters the Fire. And a man performs the deeds of the people of the Fire; until there is nothing between him and it except an arm's length, then the Book overtakes him, so he performs the deeds (1) of the people of Paradise and enters Paradise» (2).
foot_note:
1. In (Z) and (H): With the deeds. 
2. Al-Tahawi narrated it in 'Bayan Mushkil Ahadith Rasul Allah SAWS' # (3870), and Abu Awanah in his 'Mustakhraj' [See 'Ithaf Al-Maharah' (10/208)] from Yunus bin Abd al-A'la, said: Ibn Wahb informed us with it. Note: In his saying: «Indeed, a man performs the deeds...» there is disagreement; it was narrated Mawquf (stopped) on Ibn Masoud as his saying. And it was narrated Marfu' (elevated) to the Prophet (peace be upon him). Ibn Rajab Al-Hanbali said: 'It has been said: That his saying at the end of the hadith: By the One besides Whom there is no god, one of you performs the deeds of the people of Paradise, until there is... to the end of the hadith, is inserted (Mudraj) from the speech of Ibn Masoud. Salamah bin Kuhayl narrated it likewise, from Zaid bin Wahb, from Ibn Masoud as his saying. And this meaning has been narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) from multiple aspects'. 'Jami' Al-Ulum wa Al-Hikam' explanation of the fourth hadith. Al-Tahawi said: 'Regardless of what meaning this speech truly takes, from the speech of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) or from the speech of Ibn Masoud; it is truth; because Ibn Masoud is trusted regarding what he said of that if he said it, and because we know that he did not say that by opinion; because the like of it is not said by opinion, and that he only said it by reception (Tawqif), and reception is only from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)'.

(39) (z) - And Abu Muhammad; Abd al-Rahman bin Muhammad Al-Qurashi, known as Abu Sakhrah, informed us, said: Ali bin Al-Madini told us, said: Yahya bin Zakariya bin Abi Za'idah told us, said: Al-A'mash told us, from Zaid bin Wahb, from Ibn Masoud, said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) told us, and he is the Truthful and Believed One: «Indeed, the creation of one of you is gathered in his mother's womb for forty nights, then it is a clot like that, then it is a morsel like that, then the Angel is sent to it with four words, so he writes: his provision, his deed, his lifespan, and wretched or happy. So (1) one of you performs the deeds of the people of Paradise; until there is nothing between him and it except an arm's length, then the Book overtakes him; so he performs the deeds of the people of the Fire, so it is sealed for him; so he becomes of its people. So it becomes clear (3) to him. Then he says:
foot_note:
1. Thus in the three manuscripts: 'Sa'id'; and the correct reading is: 'Isa bin Hilal' as in 'Shifa Al-Alil' - where he quoted the hadith from 'Kitab Al-Qadar' by Ibn Wahb with its chain and text - and sources of referencing, and books of Rijal. 2. In 'Shifa Al-Alil' and sources of referencing: 'It is given back'. [[* Al-Siqt: The fetus that falls from its mother's womb before completion, male and female are alike in it. (Al-Siqt: with three vowels on Sin and Sukun on Qaf, and Kasra on its Sin is more common). 'Al-Lisan' (Sqt).]]

text: O Lord, one or twins? So it becomes clear to him. Then he says: O Lord, male or female? So it becomes clear to him. Then he says: O Lord, incomplete lifespan or complete lifespan? So it becomes clear to him. Then he says: O Lord, cut off his provision with his creation (1), so He decrees them both. By the One in Whose Hand is Muhammad's soul (2), he does not attain except what was apportioned to him on that day, when he consumes his provision he is taken (3). (46) - Abdullah bin Suleiman told us, said: Al-Hamdani told us, said: Ibn Wahb informed (4) us, said: Malik bin Anas informed me, from Ziyad bin Sa'd, from Amr bin Dinar, who said:
foot_note:

While in 'Al-Qadar' by Al-Firyabi, and 'Sharh Usul Al-I'tiqad' by Al-Lalaka'i it is more complete than here, and its text is: 'Then he says: O Lord, cut off his provision, so He cuts off his provision for him with his creation'.

(101, 102) from 'Kitab Al-Qadar' by Ibn Wahb with its chain and text. text: I heard Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr say in his sermon: Indeed Allah Mighty and Majestic is the Guide and the Tempter (Al-Fatin) (1). (47) (z) - Al-Hussein bin Ismail bin Muhammad; Abu Abd (2) Allah Al-Dabbi told us, said: Ahmad bin Ismail Al-Madini told us, said: Malik bin Anas told us, from Ziyad bin Sa'd, from Amr bin Dinar, that he said: I heard Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr say in his sermon: Indeed Allah is the Guide and the Tempter. (48) - Abdullah bin Suleiman bin Al-Ash'ath told us, said: Al-Hamdani told us, said: Ibn Wahb informed us, said: Abdullah bin Amr (3) informed me, from (4) Khubaib bin Abd al-Rahman, from Hafs bin Asim, from Abu Hurairah who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: «Indeed, a servant performs the deeds of the people of the Fire for seventy years, then Allah seals for him with the deeds of the people of Paradise, and indeed a servant performs the deeds of the people of (5) Paradise for seventy years, then Allah seals for him with the deeds of the people of the Fire» (6).
foot_note:
1. Malik narrated it in 'Al-Muwatta' Book of Jami', Chapter Prohibition of Speaking about Destiny (2620), and from his path: Al-Bayhaqi in 'Al-Qadar' by him (496), Al-Lalaka'i (1201), and Ibn Batta in 'Al-Ibanah' (1659). 
2. In The Original: 'Ubayd', and established from (Z) and (H). 
3. Thus in the three manuscripts 'Amr'. And the correct is: 'Umar' and perhaps this misspelling is from the copyist. And Allah knows best. 
4. In the three manuscripts: 'Bin' which is an apparent misspelling. 
5. 'People': Not in The Original and (H), and established from (Z). 
6. Al-Bazzar narrated it in his 'Musnad' [See 'Kashf Al-Astar' # (2158), and 'Mukhtasar Zawa'id Al-Bazzar' # (1614)], and Al-Tabarani in 'Al-Mu'jam Al-Awsat' # (2448) from the path of Abdullah bin Umar, from Khubaib bin Abd al-Rahman with it. Al-Haythami said: Al-Tabarani narrated it in 'Al-Awsat' and its men are men of Sahih. 'Al-Majma'' (7/212). And Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar quoted in 'Mukhtasar Al-Zawa'id' from him: Authentic! Al-Tabarani said: No one narrated this hadith from Khubaib except Abdullah. I say: And this Abdullah: is Ibn Umar bin Hafs bin Asim bin Umar bin Al-Khattab Al-Madani. Weak as in 'Al-Taqrib'. See: 'Tahdhib Al-Kamal' (15/327). Al-Iraqi said: Agreed upon from the hadith of Sahl bin Sa'd without the phrase: «seventy years». 'Al-Mughni 'an Haml Al-Asfar' # (3647). I say: Muslim narrated it # (2651) from the path of Abd al-Aziz bin Muhammad, from Al-Ala', from his father, from Abu Hurairah... so he mentioned it. Except that he said: «A long time» instead of «seventy years». And Allah knows best.

text: (49) - Abdullah bin Suleiman told us, said: Al-Hamdani told us, said: Ibn Wahb informed us, said: Abdullah bin Umar informed me, from Asim bin Ubayd (1) Allah, and Salim Abu Al-Nadr, that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: O Messenger of Allah, do we work for what the pens have run with, and destinies have dried upon, or (2) for a matter we start anew? He said: «Rather for what the pens have run with, and destinies have dried upon». He said: Then what is the point of work? He said: «Everyone is facilitated for what he was created for». He said: Now is the striving (3).
foot_note:
1. In (Z): 'Abd'. 
2. In The Original: 'Amr' (Matter), and established from (Z) and (H). 
3. Al-Daraqutni suspended it - from this path - in his 'Ilal' # (108) saying: Abdullah Al-Umari narrated it, from Asim bin Ubaydullah, and Salim Abu Al-Nadr, that Umar said: O Messenger of Allah... Mursal (disconnected). And Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi narrated it (11), Ahmad (1/29), (2/52, 77), Al-Bukhari in 'Khalq Af'al Al-Ibad' (36), Al-Tirmidhi (2135), Ibn Abi Asim in 'Al-Sunnah' # (169, 170), Al-Bazzar in his 'Musnad' # (121), Abu Ya'la # (5463, 5571), Al-Ajurri in 'Al-Shari'ah' # (326), Al-Bayhaqi in his 'Al-Qadar' # (38), and Ibn Batta in 'Al-Ibanah' # (1325) from (Muhammad bin Ja'far, Abd al-Rahman bin Mahdi, Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak, Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi, Adam, Hajjaj, Abu Jabir, Shababah bin Sawwar, and Hafs bin Umar) all of them from Shu'bah, from Asim bin Ubaydullah, from Salim bin Abdullah, from Abdullah bin Umar, from Umar bin Al-Khattab with it. It is very apparent to every observer that this aspect is more likely than the first aspect; because Abdullah Al-Umari is weak. Therefore Al-Daraqutni corrected this aspect in his 'Ilal' and not the first. 'Al-Ilal' # (108). Al-Tirmidhi said: This hadith is good authentic (Hasan Sahih). I say: Asim bin Ubaydullah: Weak according to the general opinion of scholars. Perhaps Al-Tirmidhi, may Allah have mercy on him, authenticated it due to its follow-ups and witnesses. See Hadiths (19, 20) of this book.
